newsitem.title: FRANCE: French stocks open lower, Rhone shares rally.
newsitem.headline: French stocks open lower, Rhone shares rally.

text.p: French stocks opened weaker on Friday, pressured by Wall Street's fall below 6,000 points and lower bond prices.
The blue-chip CAC-40 index was down 6.98 points or 0.32 percent at 2,144.79 at 0900 GMT while the CAC-40 October futures contract was 11.50 points lower at 2,145.50.
The bourse, which has trailed the rise in the U.S. and other European stockmarkets and remains well below its 1994 all-time high, is less volatile on the downside than other markets.
Among the CAC stocks, Rhone-Poulenc shares were up 1.82 percent at 145.10 francs after the group announced a rise in third-quarter net income to 756 million francs from 669 million.
It said that by September 30, it had sold six billion francs in non-strategic assets and expects to sell assets worth between seven and nine billion francs by the end of the year.
Lagardere shares, which have risen sharply since the government said it preferred Lagardere's bid for Thomson SA over a rival offer from Alcatel Alsthom, were down 1.65 percent at 167.20 francs.
Finance Minister Arthuis said on Thursday that Thomson's debt would be 28 billion francs at the end of the year, up from 23.8 billion at the end of 1995.
Also, the privatisation has come under political fire, notably for the one-franc sale price.

"(The newspaper) La Tribune notes that while defending the agreement, the Minister of Finance has left himself an out, noting the privatisation commission -- which is to give its verdict in mid-December -- can block the deal if it has problems with the deal," a brokerage house said in its daily comment.
